comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Lt P C Ellis, son of Clement and Florence Ellis, lived in Leek, Staffordshire, at Kniveden Hall, Mount Road. On 17 Oct 1916 he was observer / commander of a two seater Nieuport 20 reconnaissance / bomber (Tail Number A259) of No. 1 Sqn RFC, that failed to return from bombing enemy buildings with incendiaries and 20lb bombs. The pilot, 2Lt Godwin, and observer, Lt Ellis, were both killed in the crash. Their aircraft was reportedly hit by anti-aircraft fire. www.theaerodrome.com/forum/592873-post48.html and at www.theaerodrome.com/aircraft/serial_numbers.php?pageNum_... The day before, on 16 Oct 1916 Lt Godwin and Lt Ellis, possibly flying a Morane Saulnier Parasol, claimed to have shot down a Fokker D11 monoplane, reported as seen "out of control". www.theaerodrome.com/forum/159747-post8.html 2Lt C C Godwin was appointed a Flying Officer in the RFC from the Special Reserve on 18 Aug 1915 [LG 10 Sep 1915]. Lt Philip Challinor Ellis is also commemorated on the Nicholson Memorial in Leek.//

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: Philip is also remembered in the chapel of Glenalmond College warmemscot.s4.bizhat.com/warmemscot-ftopic6177.html

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: SUPPLEMENT TO THE LONDON GAZETTE, 28 NOVEMBER, 1914. 10111 The undermentioned to be temporary Second Lieutenants. Dated 28th November, 1914: — Philip Challinor Ellis. www.londongazette.co.uk/issues/28988/supplements/10111/pa... From the database of UK Soldiers who Died in the Great War: Name:Philip Challinor Ellis Death Date:17 Oct 1916 Rank:Lieutenant Regiment:Royal Flying Corps Type of Casualty:Killed in action Comments:14Th H L Born circa 1894 in the Oswestry registration district, Shropshire according to the 1901 census and birth index. Son of Clement Campbell Ellis, East India Merchant. The Ellis family lived at 48 Lancaster Gate, Paddington, London. Clement and Florence had 5 daughters aged between 2 and 14, Philip aged 7 and another son, Clement, aged 9. Clement snr. was originally from Kirkintilloch, Dunbartonshire, Scotland. In 1911 he was at 82 Lancaster Gate. His occupation was given as EAST INDIAN RICE MILLER ENGINEER and MERCHANT.
